content.body: http://heideri.ch/jso/
The page shoots itself in the foot by having "attacks" that require the attacker to be able to create on* attributes already
Sounds like "When we add new attributes, people who were blacklisting attributes are screwed".
Don't think so. Don't see why it should work for poster either.
Looks like it's just a bug in Opera
All the other cases require that the attacker already can write arbitrary markup, so I guess that's 0 new attacks
As usual.
besides the sandbox attribute, does anyone see/know of anything in html5 that will help increase security/make it easier for developers to create secure apps?
wirepair: security features are baked in from the ground up, so it's hard to point to them
hixie yeah
just wondered if something additional like sandbox would provide developers with the ability to secure their web apps
wirepair: there's things like the Origin header
wirepair: might be some other features here and there
wirepair: generally the idea is to make it automatic that things be secure, though
cool, thanks
http://beltzner.ca/mike/2010/05/10/firefox-4-fast-powerful-and-empowering/
wtf is it with slideshare
don't people realize slideshare stinks and requires a plugin
grmbl
annevk: pragmatically, it lets people do what people want
upload their powerpoints and keynote presentations
and it provides embedding functionality
http://www.learningjquery.com/2010/05/now-you-see-me-showhide-performance
krijnh server not responding>
there's no reason slideshare needs Flash
annevk: there is one.
burning CPU cycles for the glory of computing :p
What's also interesting about this CORS thing is that e.g. WebSocket has exactly the same semantics...
annevk, a consistent security models is good
*model
Indeed, but people argue against CORS but not against WebSocket
lots of people arguing against websocket for other reasons
they don't argue against websocket?
we already have enough arguments thanks :-)
hmm yes
would be a nice way to get them off my lawn :p
i'll send you some of mine!
mutually assured destruction!
heh
Hixie, you have some time for the complete.html thingy now?
sure, now's a good time
'sup
hello Hixie
hey othermaciej
I guess you want to have the copy without the absolute URLs
and I'm generating the zip file already
so long as it works, i don't mind if they're absolute or not
I guess I just need to give you a URL and you need to give one to me
i guess ping /specs/web-apps/current-work/do-multipage-complete-update
what should i fetch?
http://html5.org/complete/whatwg.org/complete.zip
just doing a wget on that URL works I suppose?
yup
or will, once i've written the script
I pm'ed the generate URL
pm'd even
thanks
I guess once that is all set up MikeSmith can remove the mailing list hook
yep
just lemme know when to flip the switch
wonders if Richard Clark is on IRC
gets his script all confused
hsivonen, hah, http://library.gnome.org/users/palimpsest/stable/advanced.html.en is brilliant
http://limpet.net/mbrubeck/2010/05/11/fennec-meta-viewport.html -- '<meta name="viewport"> is a good example of browsers innovating exactly how Sachin Agarwal thinks they should.'
it's also pretty ugly
and a layering violation
Hixie: supported by 3 of the top 4 engines. time to bite the bullet and spec it.
that's anne's problem
not really, someone can write a standalone spec for it and add it to the metaextensions wiki
ok, finally got the multipage scripts figured out
man i caused a lot of damage while doing that
whoa. http://my.opera.com/ODIN/blog/opera-mobile-10-for-nokia-n900-n800-n810-maemo-standards-support says Opera on desktop support SQL database
didn't we know that?
Hixie: I didn't.
does it use sqlite?
i assume so
yes it does
ok
http://my.opera.com/core/blog/2010/03/03/persistent-client-side-storage-for-your-persistent-needs
a bit odd not to have it on Maemo if you have it on desktop, considering WebKit's competitive position in the mobile space
so Maemo now has 3 of the top 4 browser engines available
I guess that's the broadest coverage for any mobile platform now that Gecko for Windows Mobile was discontinued
I just read that Sachin Agarwal blog post and my head exploded
roc: the post has been pretty successful at getting attention
sure
outrageous posts get attention
well I guess jetlag is at least good for data mining/archeology.
finally figured out how to get more sensible pages out of spec splitter
Hixie, maybe you should rename the id crossDocumentMessaging as it is not a very nice or consistent page name
the first mention of srt, I found on public-html is sept 2008 by Lachlan
isn't John Foliot effectively asking for addition there?
"then clear instruction and specifications on how to 'in-code' provide the out-band solution must also be provided"
annevk: yep
fun stuff
so Opera on Maemo has about zero platform integration. not even low-hanging fruit like right icon in the right menu
but the responsiveness and graphics speed is really impressive
on N800
annevk: done
cool
btw, I now have enough understanding of spec-splitter.py that I can create whatever split people desire
nice
for everyone who didn't know yet: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/
and when that copy is down: http://html5.org/complete/
looks like the reviewer script is dead on the whatwg copy there
wonder what's up with that
hmm, maybe I should use absolute links after all?
aha, no
problem with fixBrokenLink()
aha, no link-fixup.js
you have to include one of those in the zipfile, i think
can't you make the links absolute?
i mean like /path-to-script
the scripts are absoute
absolute
had a very brief image of annevk dancing at the Bolchoi and doing a split
oh, nice multipage complete version. That could be useful, though I'll stick with single page.
but you need to include a link-fixup.js specially designed for complete/'s structure
equivalent to http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/link-fixup.js
which apparently uses http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/fragment-links.js
both are provided by philip
in his tarball
ah
the problem is that script is invokes before init()
so if that script fails, init() never runs
and the other scripts don't get loaded
thanks
hopefully fixed
nice
removed the script on html5.org/complete as it doesn't work due to cross-origin issues
some will work
others not so much
does dfn.js not worm in ff?
or did i break it?
oh i broke it
nm
the notion of whitespace is such a mess
it seems various places in Gecko agree that space, \t and \n are whitespace
\r, \f and \v depend
sigh
and don't get me started about XML 1.1
Hixie: why does area coords parsing in HTML5 treat only space as a delimiter (not tab, newline, etc.)?
hsivonen: iirc for ie compat, but i'm not 100% sure
zcorpan_: What do Opera and WebKit do?
Gecko accepts even \v!
hsivonen: opera implements the spec, or possibly an earlier version of the spec where there was no special treatment for funny characters or something
hsivonen: don't remember what webkit does
zcorpan_: ok
I'll file this away, because these other whitespace bugs are distracting me from the whitespace bug I'm trying to fix
http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html/2009Jan/0079.html ?
Filed as https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=565031
hsivonen: i don't mind changing the spec wrt whitespace in coords
hsivonen, isn't XML 1.1 dead?
I wonder why the chairs are so vocal about splitting... I guess there was some backchannel chatter
annevk: I think it has a lot to do with keeping the choice of external text format independent of HTML5
png, jpeg, ogg, mpeg4 - none of these are specified as part of HTML5
and nor should they by - there may be better formats in the future that the video, audio and img elements will have to support!
it's really the same for external text associations for video and audio and a format definition should not be inside the spec
text/cache-manifest is in HTML5
as are text/ping, text/html-sandboxed, application/microdata+json

Has anyone argued that it *should* be defined in the HTML5 document? (rather than arguing that it doesn't matter where the text exists for now and it's a waste of effort to worry about it before we even know whether it's a good enough solution that it should continue to exist)
Ian has
Ah
annevk: are those supposed to be used outside the Web by other apps, too?
nessy, whether there will be better formats in the future is somewhat orthogonal to where formats are specified
not if the only format that is acceptable is the one inside the spec
nessy, at least where the consensus is clear — with the img element — it would be good to document it. after all, png, gif, jpeg ARE all supported in almost every browser.
if we want to make more formats acceptable we change the spec
without baseline formats you get compatibility nightmares
what annevk said.
you can call a format a baseline format without having it specified inside the spec
we wouldn't include the theora specification into html5, either, to make it a baseline format
nessy, how would an implementor know then if it isn't included ?
a mere sentence that this is the baseline format and a link to its specification would be completely sufficient
honestly, my mind boggles at the sheer idea that somebody implementing support for WebSRT in their desktop captioning application has to deal with the whole HTML5 spec!
why would they have to deal with the whole spec?
because as it's part of the HTML5 spec, how will they know there is nothing in the rest of the spec that is not relevant to their implementation
also these are not the reasons brought forward for splitting
they are my reasons
sure
and I have brought them forward
sure
but they are not what started this IRC thread :)
oh!
anyway, it seems that simply reading the WebSRT section should give them all the answers
seems I have to keep up with the spec reading!
e.g. text/cache-manifest might get separate tool support as well
it's pretty easy to just read the part on text/cache-manifest to figure out how to construct such files and how to read them (e.g. if you write some kind of optimization tool)
some definitions are reused but they are all clearly hyperlinked
I don't really see what all the fuss is about; it mostly seems a lot of hand waving without much clear scenarios
look at it this way: software is not written as one big main function either - stuff that is reused elsewhere is split into libraries - WebSRT is a "library" for me
and the spec is too long for its own good anyway - takes ages to load in any browser!
annevk: Some aspects of XML 1.1 are undead, though
btw: does anyone know why the links in the ToC at http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html don't work?
I guess it's just the #websrt one that doesn't ...
nessy: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/video.html#websrt loads faster
yeah, I know, but I wanted to check what's in the w3c's spec
I always use the whatwg link :)
Oops, I got confused and forgot it was still in the HTML5 documents too
hmm… it seems it had to do with the page not being properly loaded by my browser - forget it :)
nessy: that link probably doesn't work because that section is recently added and so the splitter has generated a new output file for it, and I've not yet committed that to cvs
I'll take a look noew
it worked after a reaload actually
nothing to worry about
hsivonen, fwiw, treating CR as TAB without tab stops is not something I really understand
re spaces; here's a list of all the one I know:

\u0020 //SPACE | \u00A0 //NO-BREAK SPACE | \u1361 //ETHIOPIC WORDSPACE | \u1680 //OGHAM SPACE MARK | \u2002 //EN SPACE | \u2003 //EM SPACE | \u2004 //THREE-PER-EM SPACE | \u2005 //FOUR-PER-EM SPACE | \u2006 //SIX-PER-EM SPACE | \u2007 //FIGURE SPACE | \u2008 //PUNCTUATION SPACE | \u2009 //THIN SPACE | \u200A //HAIR SPACE | \u200B //ZERO WIDTH SPACE | \u202F //NARROW NO-BREAK SPACE | \u205F //MEDIUM MATHEMATICAL SPACE | \u2408
oh hey webr3, didn't know you were on IRC
yeah i am
almost feel like saying sorry about the noise; but at the same time i see it as an issue, that probably can't be addressed! web's safe so it's cool
http://simon.html5.org/dump/ecmascript-whitespace.txt
zcorpan_: cheers
the "opera" column is out of date
webr3, discussion is good
zcorpan_ maybe check for \u303F - is missing off that page
annevk: agreed
webr3: i checked for all of BMP
in o10.5x i get:
definitive list, I'll update my trim()'s!
note that this is whitespace in ecmascript eval()
whitespace in ecmascript source is hopefully the same
but whitespace in other places is different
"other places"?
i mean like in html and css
Ah
Well yes, ECMAScript says "all other characters in unicode class Zs" or something
HTML has a shor fixed list
*short
(ECMAScript also has a short list or doesn't-matter-what-unicode-says characters)
the ecmascript definition is annoying because it doesn't say which version of unicode, just requires unicode 2.0 or later (or something)
and it changes over time
Indeed
pretty great that we are now at the point where we can argue over whitespace definitions rather than all the shit we had to emulate from IE6 :p
Unicode 3.0
(it says "must... Unicode 3.0 ... may ... later versions")
(of course, it's not quite like that, but it certainly has improved)
(so even if characters are moved out of Zs in later versions, tehy still have to be recognised as whitespace)
(which has happened a couple of times iirc)
wait what?
oh god
annevk: ?
you pointing out it's as inconsistent as hell
Well not really
It's slightly more consistent than just saying "whatever versuion of unicode you like"
slightly less consistent than saying "just this set of characters"
Unicode versions are a pain no matter how you handle them...
jgraham, latest version would have been more consistent
relying on specifications not evolving is silly and codifying it is worse

I like the Chinese examples
hehehe
naughty me
Dashiva: do you understand Chinese, or are you just exceptionally clued on about Chinese internet memes?
boblet: nice work
The latter
hey Mike! thanks man

Translations, clarificatioins, all kinds of weird stuff

The ruby is ... Japanese transliterations of the English words for the translated Japanese
MikeSmith: you gonna be around next Tue-Thur? I’ll be in town. would be nice to catch up — maybe the W3 mixed rotenburo trip Naoko was talking about?
Dashiva: it’s mainly just furigana and romaji for kanji pronunciation
http://dashiva.net/misc/baldr08.jpg
This one made me smile
hehe
boblet: will be at home, yeah

hsivonen: I think there's a typo in your moz post "the more maintainable code base of the HTML5 compared to Gecko’s old HTML parser." -> "the more maintainable code base of the HTML5 parser compared to Gecko’s old HTML parser."
hsivonen: also, "<DOCTYPE !html>" -> "<!DOCTYPE html>"
was just about to point that out :)
but overall, a nice summary, thanks, hsivonen
shepazutoo: thanks. forwarded to blizzard
Ahoy!
shepazutoo: fixed. thanks
http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2010/05/giving-voice-to-more-languages-on.html -- hmm eSpeak is GPL; I wonder what loophole is being used here
annevk: They're not distributing compiled code that contains eSpeak, so the GPL obligations on releasing source code don't apply
Aah, so GPL can be "abused" by server applications?
Yes
(if you consider it abuse)
The people who drafted it probably do
The Affero GPL is designed to prevent that situation
Seems like quite the loophole given all the "cloud" thingies going on
I wonder if you could sell something and include "You must forfeit your GPL-granted rights for this product" in the contract terms
You can include anything you want in the contract terms
People will probably happily agree to it too
But would it be legally solid?
The GPL says "You may not impose any further restrictions on the exercise of the rights granted or affirmed under this License." which sounds like you could argue it covers that situation
Sounds like it, yeah
"a durable physical medium customarily used for software interchange"
Like floppies!
Is there any way to blur out an image from JavaScript?  Like you have some image at a URL, and you want to include that image, but blurred.  Is this something canvas can do somehow?
knows nothing about image stuff
i've seen a js lib that does that i think
looks
aha. AryehGregor: http://www.pixastic.com/lib/docs/actions/blur/
http://www.pixastic.com/lib/docs/actions/blurfast/ is way more intense
Yeah.
That's what I'm looking for.
Hmm, MPL 1.1.
That's not GPL-compatible, is it?
Well, probably no one's looking too hard.
has no idea
It's probably fine if I keep it served in totally separate files, I guess.
AryehGregor: you could use an svg filter
Seems like there's a library to do it, which already uses canvas+IE filters for IE.
Good enough for me.
canvas???
SVG filters would perform a lot better
SVG isn't a cool new toy, though
svg filters in text/html is a cool new toy
it doesn't even work in any shipping browser
zcorpan_: svg filters in text/html works in Firefox 3.5 and later
you just put the filter in an external SVG file
